awd_abstract_narration:
The planned research develops and applies tools of the field of microlocal analysis. Roughly speaking, this field keeps track of the position and frequency, or momentum, of waves (or more generally, functions) simultaneously. The planned applications are to wave propagation and other related phenomena, as well as inverse problems for determining a function from integrals along curves (X-ray transform) and related problems for determining the structure of a material from boundary measurements. Although the proposal concerns their mathematical theory, these problems are closely connected to the physical world. Wave propagation is ubiquitous in nature, with electromagnetic waves, such as light, being one of the most prevalent examples. The theory of general relativity is another important physical example via (the not long ago detected) gravitational waves: the PI’s recent work with Hintz showed that in a universe with a (possibly small, as our universe is currently understood) positive cosmological constant, perturbations of black holes decay to a slightly different black hole, emitting gravitational waves in the process. Scattering theory of quantum particles (such as protons and electrons) is another subject governed by microlocal analysis: these aspects enter both into the description of quantum waves at large distances. The inverse problems under study are also of broad significance: an application of the theory developed here is the determination of an unknown variable speed of elastic waves in an object via the measurement of travel times of waves, which for instance is relevant to imaging to interior of Earth using the travel times of earthquake waves. Many of the projects are suitable for research by doctoral students, and the PI strives to contribute to the education of a new generation of mathematicians and scientists.

Some of the proposed projects describe the long-time or far field behavior of waves on curved space-times. Physically these arise in general relativity, including electromagnetic waves on a curved background. The microlocal approach to analysis on these spaces has made breakthroughs possible in the PI's work on linear and non-linear (with his former PhD student, P. Hintz) problems on asymptotically hyperbolic (AH) spaces as well as Kerr-de Sitter (KdS) space (rotating black holes in a cosmological spacetime), culminating in the proof of the stability of slowly rotating KdS spaces with Hintz. More recently, with Hafner and Hintz the PI extended some of these tools to the vanishing cosmological constant case (Minkowski, Kerr). The projects here aim to extend these tools to further spaces, such as perturbations of Kerr spacetimes, and also to study other equations on cosmological spacetimes. Other projects study basic objects in quantum field theory, in particular the Feynman propagator. Another main area is inverse problems, where the PI, together with Uhlmann, has introduced new tools for the spatially localized inversion of the geodesic X-ray transform, and with Stefanov and Uhlmann extended this to the boundary rigidity problem. One project here aims to extend this to anisotropic elasticity which plays an important role in the interior of the Earth. Another project with the PI's former postdoc Wang studies the light ray transform with potential applications to imaging by the cosmic background radiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to use phase space, or microlocal, techniques to analyze various problems. In physical problems, these microlocal techniques keep track of position and momentum at the same time, to the extent that it is allowed by Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle.

A typical application is to describe wave-type equations, including the asymptotic behavior far away. Wave-type equations describe, for instance, the propagation of electromagnetic (light), elastic and gravitational waves. The results of the project describe how waves behave.

One of the applications was for the analysis of wave equations and of Einstein's equation in general relativity on Kerr and Kerr-de Sitter space-times. These are rotating black hole space-times that describe either an asymptotically flat universe (Kerr) or a cosmological universe (Kerr-de Sitter); the former are thus good approximations of isolated stellar mass black holes while the latter describe black holes in our universe with an accelerating expansion. Earlier collaborative work of the PI showed the stability of slowly rotating Kerr-de Sitter black holes (with Hintz) as well as the linearized stability (a weaker notion) of slowly rotating Kerr black holes (with Haefner and Hintz), namely if these space-times are perturbed, then they will settle back to another similar black hole space-time, although potentially with a slightly different mass and angular momentum. In the current period the PI with his postdoc, Petersen, showed that the analysis of waves used in the black hole stability work extends to all subextremal (so including very fast rotating) Kerr-de Sitter black holes, bringing the potential proof of their stability closer. In addition, the PI and Hintz showed how to extend the microlocal tools to asymptotically flat black hole space times perturbed by radiation.

 Another application is to inverse problems. In earth sciences a common way to obtain information about the interior of Earth is via seismic (elastic) waves which travel through this interior. A relatively simple quantity one can measure is the travel time of waves generated by earthquakes to far away locations on the surface of the Earth; the `inverse problem' is to find out the propagation speed of waves in the interior (and thus infer what the materials and physical conditions are). In this project a mathematically precise analysis of a slightly simplified problem was given; this simplification is assuming that the materials are transversely isotropic, i.e. have a preferred axis, around which they are rotationally symmetric, which is expected to be the case on sufficiently large scales in effective models of the Earth. The results, with collaborators and also of the PI's PhD student roughly give that the travel times indeed determine, even when only localized information is given, certain aspects, such as the axis of isotropy and some material parameters, of the structure inside (at least locally, if only local information is given) under suitable conditions, and indeed they do so in such a way that potentially one can implement the result numerically.

 In a more geometric aspect of the project, a linearized version of this travel time tomography problem, called X-ray tomography (which generalizes the customary CT scan), was studied by the PI and PhD students on spaces that are conic near infinity, for instance are asymptotically Euclidean. These results extended the former localized results (domains such as the Earth) of the PI and collaborators to this novel setting, which possesses a spatial infinity, under natural geometric restrictions. In the process, even in the original travel time setting, the PI introduced a new method that under some geometric conditions (roughly that certain waves do not re-focus) eliminates the need for the use of the more complicated tools and proceeds in a single step rather than the `layer stripping' approach of the PI and Uhlmann. 

 An important part of this project was to provide research experience to PhD students and develop the research skills of postdocs, as well as to communicate the results in a manner that is accessible to a broader mathematical audience.
